headline: Trillion-Dollar Tech Wipeout Ensnares All Stocks in AI’s Path
summary: Nothing, though, quite rivals the rout rippling through stock and credit markets this week.  In the span of two days, hundreds of billions of dollars were wiped off the value of stocks, bonds and loans of companies big and small across Silicon Valley.  “I don’t think it is an overreaction,” said Michael O’Rourke, chief market strategist at Jonestrading.

headline: US software stocks stabilize after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears
summary: Software and data services stocks stabilized on Thursday after a bruising selloff, as investors looked for clues on whether fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools are starting to dent ​demand for traditional software and subscription businesses.  The S&P 500 software and services index has shed more than $800 billion in ‌market value over the past six sessions.  Price performance of overseas tech stocks was also mixed.

headline: Is Salesforce (CRM) Now Offering Value After A Sharp 42% Share Price Slide?
summary: If you are wondering whether Salesforce at around US$199 a share looks like a bargain or a value trap, you are not alone. The stock has seen sharp moves recently, with a 12.5% decline over the last 7 days, a 22.2% decline over the last 30 days, and a 42.3% decline over the last year, although the 3 year return sits at 19.0%. These swings have kept Salesforce in the spotlight, as investors weigh its role in enterprise software and customer relationship management against changing expectations...

summary: Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT) secured a Foreign Military Sales contract to supply IRST21 Legion-ES infrared sensing systems to Taiwan's Air Force, making Taiwan the first international partner for this technology. headline: US software stocks mixed after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies were mixed on Thursday after a bruising selloff earlier this week that was triggered by fears that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools ​could upend the sector.  Shares of London Stock Exchange Group added 6.1%, while data analytics firms RELX rose 2.8% and the Netherlands-based Wolters Kluwer gained 2%.  In contrast, India's software exporters index, which houses names such as HCL Technologies and Wipro, slipped 0.7%, a day after plunging 6% in its worst session in nearly six years.

content.title: US software stocks mixed after bruising selloff on AI disruption fears
content.summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies were mixed on Thursday after a bruising selloff earlier this week that was triggered by fears that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools ​could upend the sector.  Shares of London Stock Exchange Group added 6.1%, while data analytics firms RELX rose 2.8% and the Netherlands-based Wolters Kluwer gained 2%.  In contrast, India's software exporters index, which houses names such as HCL Technologies and Wipro, slipped 0.7%, a day after plunging 6% in its worst session in nearly six years.

headline: US software shares extend declines on mounting fears over AI disruption
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies extended their steep slide into a seventh session on Thursday as investors continued to pull back on fears that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could upend the sector.  Canada-based Thomson Reuters, which suffered ‌a record one-day plunge earlier this week after investors raised concerns that a new plug-in from Anthropic's Claude could disrupt its legal business, erased early gains to fall 4.9% despite raising its dividend and reporting fourth-quarter results largely in line with estimates.  The company, which owns the Westlaw legal database and the Reuters news agency, said it was seeing tangible benefits from AI investments.

content.title: US software shares extend declines on mounting fears over AI disruption

The company, which owns the Westlaw legal database and the Reuters news agency, said it was seeing tangible benefits from AI investments.

headline: Anthropic releases AI upgrade as market punishes software stocks
summary: Technology startup Anthropic on Thursday launched what it called an improved artificial intelligence model, days after its product advances helped ​kick-start a selloff of traditional software stocks.  The San Francisco-based lab, which is backed ‌by Amazon.com and Alphabet's Google, said its Claude Opus 4.6 model is an upgrade to the Opus 4.5 ‌model released in November.  The new AI can work on tasks for longer and more reliably, while showing gains related to coding and finance, Anthropic said.

content.title: Anthropic releases AI upgrade as market punishes software stocks
content.summary: Technology startup Anthropic on Thursday launched what it called an improved artificial intelligence model, days after its product advances helped ​kick-start a selloff of traditional software stocks.  The San Francisco-based lab, which is backed ‌by Amazon.com and Alphabet's Google, said its Claude Opus 4.6 model is an upgrade to the Opus 4.5 ‌model released in November.  The new AI can work on tasks for longer and more reliably, while showing gains related to coding and finance, Anthropic said.

headline: US software shares sink further on mounting fears over AI disruption
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies extended their steep slide for a seventh straight session on Thursday as investors worried that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could upend the sector.  Canada-based Thomson Reuters , which suffered a record one-day plunge earlier this week after investors raised concerns that a new plug-in from Anthropic's Claude could disrupt its legal ‌business, erased early gains to fall 9% despite raising its dividend and reporting fourth-quarter results largely in line with estimates.  The company, which owns the Westlaw legal database and the Reuters news agency, said it was seeing tangible benefits from AI investments.

Canada-based Thomson Reuters , which suffered a record one-day plunge earlier this week after investors raised concerns that a new plug-in from Anthropic's Claude could disrupt its legal ‌business, erased early gains to fall 9% despite raising its dividend and reporting fourth-quarter results largely in line with estimates.  The company, which owns the Westlaw legal database and the Reuters news agency, said it was seeing tangible benefits from AI investments.

headline: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
summary:
STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.

As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment."

"For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

content.title: 'Software-mageddon' unlikely to be broad-based, market expert says
content.summary:
STORY: Investors have unloaded shares of companies such as ServiceNow and Salesforce on worries that rapidly improving AI tools could eat into demand for traditional software, squeezing profit margins across the sector.

As for how things will shake out, Dhargalkar said that "like most market disruptions and downturns, and even upswings, it's never clear in the moment."

"For example, some of the larger enterprise firms, software firms, they may actually find AI to be an enabling tool rather than a disruptive tool," he explained. "Whereas it's possible that for smaller SaaS (software as a service) or single-point type of solutions, they may have a much harder time overcoming this perception that there will be internally built software that can compete with external solutions for a lot of these enterprises."

headline: Salesforce Army Megadeal Tests AI Vision And Leadership Stability
summary: Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) secured a US$5.6b, 10-year contract with the US Army, expanding its role as a core software provider to a major government customer. The deal coincides with leadership changes, including departures at Tableau and Slack, as the company responds to rising concerns about AI-driven disruption in enterprise software. Investors are weighing the long-term implications of deeper public sector ties against questions about Salesforce's organizational stability and product...

Investors are weighing the long-term implications of deeper public sector ties against questions about Salesforce's organizational stability and product...

headline: US software stocks slammed on mounting fears over AI disruption, lose $1 trillion in week
summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies extended their tumble for a seventh straight session on Thursday as investors worried that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could upend the sector.  The S&P 500 software and services index dropped 4.6%, having shed about $1 trillion in market value ​since January 28, in a selloff dubbed "software-mageddon."  "I would classify this as a sell-everything mindset at this point," said Dave Harrison Smith, chief investment officer and head of technology investing at asset management firm Bailard.

content.title: US software stocks slammed on mounting fears over AI disruption, lose $1 trillion in week
content.summary: Shares of U.S. software and data services companies extended their tumble for a seventh straight session on Thursday as investors worried that fast-advancing artificial intelligence tools could upend the sector.  The S&P 500 software and services index dropped 4.6%, having shed about $1 trillion in market value ​since January 28, in a selloff dubbed "software-mageddon."  "I would classify this as a sell-everything mindset at this point," said Dave Harrison Smith, chief investment officer and head of technology investing at asset management firm Bailard.
